It suggested broadening the scope of the local amusement tax as a way to boost earnings, as “LGUs should not only rely on the fiscal support and allocations from the national government.” Revenue collections from amusement taxes may be insignificant compared to others, but these still contribute to state coffers, the think tank emphasized. Local and national amusement taxes collected reached P887.72 million and P134.50 million, respectively, from 2014 to 2018, according to the report. The cancellation of several entertainment events on account of the pandemic resulted in lower revenues in the Greater Manila Area, where almost half of these came from. The government banned them at the onset of the pandemic, as they encourage mass gatherings that would allow the coronavirus to spread. The estimated revenue loss from taxes collected from SM Prime Holdings Inc. — which operates the Sy Group’s shopping malls, as well as cinemas — alone amounted to P376.39 million at end-September 2020. “As it stands and as construed by the Supreme Court in various cases, Section 140 of the LGC (Local Government Code) of 1991, as amended, is limited only to theaters, cinemas, concert halls, circuses and other places of amusement where one seeks admission to entertain oneself by seeing or viewing the show or performance,” the report said. “In this regard, the coverage of local amusement tax may be broadened to include places that may be considered as places of amusement. In addition, the phrase ‘places of amusement’ must be defined appropriately so as to include other establishments that may be considered as such,” it added. While the pandemic suspended or canceled most shows and programs, there are online streaming shows that can be regarded as sources of amusement, according to the NTRC, noting that people are watching them at home amid the state-imposed mobility restrictions. “The LGUs can tap these sites as sources of tax revenues as the country [adapts to] the new normal,” it said. “LGUs need a broader range of revenue tools. These should include revenue sources that automatically grow with the economy, and at present live streaming may be closely considered as an additional revenue source of LGUs,” the think tank added. “However, it is crucial that social and economic issues are taken into consideration so that new funding sources shift costs fairly on those who can most afford to pay.” The administrative aspect of imposing this tax should also be considered, according to the NTRC. “Congress should consider reviewing the LGC of 1991, as amended, to align the limitations and taxing powers of LGUs to modern business models. For instance, expanding the coverage of local amusement tax may be explored by policymakers to provide additional revenue to LGUs,” it said. “Expanding the local amusement tax coverage will give sufficient leeway for the local sanggunian (council) to explore other activities that may be covered by the local amusement tax,” it added.

titles: Cebu bishop, priest test positive for Covid-19
articles_content: Retired Auxiliary Bishop Antonio Rañola tested positive for Covid-19, the Catholic Bishops Conference of the Philippines (CBCP) and the Cebu Archdiocese said in a statement. The 88-year old Rañola, who stays in the same residence with Archbishop Jose Palma of Cebu, was rushed to a hospital in the city on Friday due to severe coughing. The CBCP said Rañola in stable condition. “His vital signs are stable and he is also under close medical supervision by his doctors,” it said in a statement. The CBCP said that Fr. Russel Sungcad was also hospitalized because of Covid-19. He is now in stable condition. Sungcad is currently assigned at the Alliance of Two Hearts Parish in Cebu City’s Banawa district.

titles: Coronavirus vaccines in the world of make-believe
articles_content: For weeks now, authorities fighting the pandemic have been simulating the arrival of Covid-19 vaccines and mass inoculations. Of course, it is always better to be prepared. As Benjamin Franklin said, “By failing to prepare, you are preparing to fail.” But with delay after delay in the arrival, the dry runs are becoming less virtuous and more comedic. A Manila health worker shows how to aspire a Covid-19 vaccine from a mock vial, during a mass vaccination simulation activity for senior citizens inside the Legarda Elementary School in Sampaloc, Manila, on 18 February 2021. PHOTO BY MIKE ALQUINTO Indeed, the latest from the Palace is that even President Rodrigo Duterte has grown impatient with the delays. That should have been reassuring, until we remember that he heads the government that is on the receiving end of the blame. Doses of the Pfizer-BioNTech’s Covid-19 vaccine from the Covax Facility were supposed to arrive by mid-February, but delivery was snagged because of vague issues surrounding the indemnity agreement. Also, the 600,000 doses of China’s Sinovac Biotech vaccine expected to arrive on February 23 may also be delayed because the manufacturer has yet to secure emergency use authorization from the local Food and Drug Administration. With frustration growing, the government now has to parry more criticisms than usual. Vice President Maria Leonor “Leni” Robredo, along with other government critics like Sen. Ana Theresia “Risa” Hontiveros, pointed out that even less developed countries like Bangladesh have started inoculations. The observation may be factual but perhaps out of context. Such statements only add to the absurd play and are helpful only in scoring cheap political points. United Nations Secretary-General Antonio Guterres offered a broader perspective on the matter. He said he was alarmed by the global disparity of vaccine distribution. He pointed out that 130 countries have yet to receive vaccines, and that only 10 nations have administered 75 percent of the doses available. Guterres also appealed to the Group of 20 or G20 to bear more of the responsibility for financing and implementing vaccination programs around the world, saying the UN will provide them its full support. “If the virus is allowed to spread like wildfire in the Global South, it will mutate again and again. New variants could become more transmissible, more deadly and, potentially, threaten the effectiveness of current vaccines and diagnostics,” he explained in a story by Agence France-Presse. “This can prolong the pandemic significantly, enabling the virus to come back to plague the Global North.” Those fears are proving to be prophetic. Just on Saturday, The Manila Times reported that two new Covid-19 variants were discovered in Central Visayas. Health experts are still studying these variants, but mutations found elsewhere in the world seem to be more transmissible and virulent, possibly even resistant to the vaccines now being distributed. Consequences of delays Besides more people falling ill or dying, the delays in vaccination will likely spawn black markets and encourage criminal activities. That may already be happening, and if this is true, the situation becomes more complicated for the Duterte government. A few months ago, when media uncovered that the President’s security detail received Covid-19 shots that were smuggled into the country, there were also reports that thousands of Chinese expatriates and Chinese Filipinos had been vaccinated somehow. As we mentioned before in this space, a local black market for vaccines may have already emerged. With people desperate for protection from the pandemic and with the country eager to restart the economy, more may become susceptible to all sorts of schemes. Getting authentic vaccines through unlawful means is one thing, but what if people are duped into paying for fake shots or being injected with placebos? Can buyers tell whether they are getting a flu shot instead of a tested Covid-19 vaccine? Sadly, this issue subsided when President Duterte himself objected to an investigation of the Presidential Security Group (PSG). For the sake of protecting the PSG, there was no directive to look into the vaccine black market. That is yet another act in this unfolding horseplay. The public is distracted by the illusion of movement from simulations, but there is hardly any action. The government needs to get its act together somehow, despite the global issues. More than anything else, that would help bring down the curtains on this tiresome tragedy.

titles: PH logs 2,240 new cases, highest in Feb
articles_content:
THE Philippines registered 2,240 new coronavirus disease 2019 (Covid-19) cases on Saturday, its highest in nearly a month, according to the Department of Health (DoH). The highest number of infections registered so far was 2,245 on January 27. Total active cases are at 34,100, of which more than 95 percent are either mild, moderate, or asymptomatic while the rest are severe or critical. There are 513,120 recoveries, including 504 new survivors while 239 more people died, raising the toll to 12,068.

Of the 24,165 samples tested, 1,652 were positive for a positivity rate of 6.8 percent.

Across the globe, coronavirus cases are at 110.7 million, with 2.45 million dead.

titles: Cebu archbishop tests positive for Covid-19
articles_content:
CEBU Archbishop Jose Palma has tested positive for the coronavirus disease 2019 (Covid-19). “He (Palma) tested positive at 10 p.m. (Thursday),” said Msgr. Joseph Tan, the Cebu Archdiocese spokesperson, on Friday. The archbishop, according to Tan, was feeling unwell on Thursday and wanted to be brought to a hospital. “His body felt tired. He was coughing and felt really tired. So, he had a swab test,” he told The Manila Times in Visayan. Palma was brought to Perpetual Succour Hospital where he was confined and is reported to be in stable condition. Tan said Palma did not have any recent travels outside Cebu, and they do not have any idea where the archbishop could have contracted the virus. “Our main concern is to make sure he gets out of the hospital,” the spokesperson added.
Tan said the archbishop’s symptoms included general fatigue and mild cough. “Let us all pray for his steady and speedy recovery,” the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Cebu said in a statement.

titles: PH logs 1,901 new Covid-19 cases
articles_content: THE Philippines has logged 1,901 new cases of coronavirus disease 2019 (Covid-19), raising the count to 557,058, according to the Department of Health (DoH). Of the 32,440 active cases, 95 percent are mild, moderate, and asymptomatic, while the rest remain severe and critical, A total of 512,789 have recovered while the death toll has climbed to 11,829. The positivity rate is at 5.9 percent, with 1,605 out of 27,335 tests by all but four Covid-19 laboratories yielding positive results. There are 110.3 million infections and 2.44 million deaths, according to Johns Hopkins University.

titles: 2 Covid mutations detected in Central Visayas samples
articles_content: TWO “mutations of clinical concern” of the coronavirus disease 2019 (Covid-19) were found in the samples that were sequenced from Central Visayas, according to the Inter-Agency Task Force on Emerging New Variants. According to Dr. Cynthia Saloma, University of the Philippines-Philippine Genome Center (UP-PGC) director, the E484K and the N501Y mutations were detected in 31 out the 70 samples that came from the region during the sequencing made by the center on February 11. “These are mutations of global concern that were exhibited by variants of concern tulad ng nasa (like in) South Africa, yung sa Brazil and yung sa United Kingdom,” Saloma said in a press conference on Friday. Saloma said the “silent” mutation of the SARS-CoV2 (Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome-coronavirus 2) virus was brought about by changes in the sequence of its deoxyribonucleic or ribonucleic acid (DNA/RNA) pairs, and can either cause a loss, gain in function or possibly no change at all. The variants are considered viruses that developed from a specific group of mutations, causing them to behave differently from the strain they originated from. Both mutations can either increase the transmission of Covid-19 and reduce the efficacy of the current vaccines in use, according to Saloma. The cases with these mutations had only exhibited mild symptoms and were cleared. Saloma added that the PGC Genomic Biosurveillance team and the DoH epidemiology bureau will now closely check the genome sequences of the samples and monitor the cases that had been infected with these mutations. Despite the discovery of the new mutations in Central Visayas, Health Secretary Francisco Duque 3rd said that this may not affect Metro Manila’s planned shift to modified general community quarantine (MGCQ) by March 1 as long as the region is careful in enforcing a more relaxed status. “We have to scale up even more in the light of these variants… our massive promotion to let the public comply with all of our minimum public health standards, and the aggressive early detection by way of testing, tracing and isolation,” Duque said.

titles: Secure and insecure citizenship
articles_content:
I WAS debating whether to write another article on Covid-19 having first read a very intelligent article in The Atlantic and given the misinformation being peddled by others. There are those who for their personal reasons have an ideological bias that overcomes fact and reason, but I decided against another article that would marginally be bringing up new points given all the major ones that have already been set forth. Maybe if it was substantially on points not previously raised or new verified information rather than rehashing whatever one’s bias dictates and quoting prejudiced sources. On the topic, I am not discussing what is the way we should apply our citizenship laws. While I did work at the Romulo Law Office and passed the bar, my legal career ended in 1984, and I do not pretend to be up to date or remember enough of what I was ably taught decades ago. This is about our attitude toward citizenship and contrast that with others. Many may take issue with my observations, but that is what reasoned discourse is about. I have observed that generally, the more secure a country is, the more liberal their citizenship laws. The less differences in citizenship rights between natural and naturalized, the more open-minded their attitude toward citizenship is. Same is true on how straightforward and open the country is to naturalization. An exception to this is Japan, where like the Philippines one only gets citizenship through jus sanguinis (bloodline — so a parent must be a citizen to bestow citizenship on a child) vs jus soli (where you are born). Places like the US and UK give both jus sanguinis and soli. In Japan you have people who legally work and stay there for generations but because of bloodline never become citizens. That would be the case here as well unless you opt for naturalization. Ironically, it often seems the stricter the citizenship laws, the less desirable the country often is for citizenship anyway. These tend to be the jus sanguinis only countries. Jus soli or jus sanguinis
Why do countries like the US (though the nativist and racist Trump talked about changing it and fortunately his losing ends that immediate fear) apply jus soli? Why do they grant citizenship if you were born there and have for immigrants a relatively straightforward path to citizenship? First, these tend to be countries that had high immigration in their formative years and encouraged it (though the US also has swung the other way under Trump and had its shameful racist periods like the Chinese Exclusion Act and the Japanese incarceration in times of backlash and xenophobia). Second, they tend to be successful and secure countries that argue if you stay here it is because you want to and believe it, to use the popular phrase, to be “the land of opportunity.” Let us not digress into talk among elites who argue about their privileges and so on here vs there. I am talking about opportunity in spite of challenges overall. Those countries are generally not worried that you are going there to exploit the country. You are going there to be part of it. You have bought into their narrative or at least believe that for all the challenges, the opportunities there are better than back home. My one digression that really gets me angry is when people tout the Philippines as paradise because you can have maids and personal help en masse. Guess what? Maybe it is paradise for those who have maids. It is far from paradise for the ones rendering the service. To many and I agree, it is a sign of advancement and civilization that there are enough opportunities in a country that many do not have to be domestic help and if they do so, are compensated enough so it is at least partially a choice rather than something one does for lack of choice or to survive. A paradise is one that is paradise for all or most. Not some tiny sliver only. When my family and I lived in the US, we had no live-in or full-time help. If you needed or wanted someone to come in to clean the house or mow the lawn you contracted with a service, and they would come over, often as a team and do what they needed to in a few hours and then would come back depending on your schedule weekly or as one needed or scheduled. In New York City, it is often an individual rather than a team given most have apartments. Also, the society is structured so you do not need live-in or permanent help to have a comfortable life. The only exception is if you have very young children; then the need to arrange reliable baby-sitters is a chore and can be a challenge. Hence one often sees parents bringing their infants with them to restaurants, cinemas and the like. Related to this is the comment I often hear which is, why do Filipinos do well when abroad? I think it is in large part that our country, 75 years after independence, has not delivered for its ever-increasing population. In our region, Malaysia and Thailand have and Vietnam is clearly on its way to doing so. I remember being so proud after 1986 and so sad for China after 1989. Let us be blunt, absent surface political rights (and I say surface and superficial because who really benefits and can make use of our democratic rights), who is better off if we take conditions prevailing in 1990 as the starting point? On both an individual and country level — the Philippines or China? The answer except for political dissidents is so sadly and blatantly obvious. To go back to the question, why do Filipinos do well abroad while the country underperforms? I used to say, the biggest vote in the Philippines is not the vote for this or that candidate. It is the vote to leave, which tens of millions of Filipinos have taken and continue to take. In my view, Filipinos do well abroad for two reasons — simply because they are incentivized to do so and generally those who go abroad are the more aggressive and adventurous ones. Let us assume you are in a middle position, not happy but not unhappy. Which type of person chooses to stay and which chooses to try something different elsewhere? Who is willing to be away from their families, friends, comfort zone and environment? The latter might not be smarter or wiser and it may be the wrong decision, but that person is definitely more adventurous and open to new ideas and challenges. Guess what? That is what they say in other countries as well, where there is a diaspora until the home country becomes successful and many return home. Natural-born vs naturalized
An offshoot of this is the different rights of natural-born and naturalized citizens. In the US, I think the only differentiator I know is that only a natural-born citizen can be president and if there was fraud in the naturalization process, citizenship can be rescinded. A natural-born citizen cannot have this citizenship removed or revoked. The US requires certain industries like media and transportation and their CEOs to be American. They do not distinguish between natural and naturalized. When he bought the New York Post decades ago, Rupert Murdoch acquired American citizenship to enable himself to be a publisher. Same thing with elected and appointed government officials below president. There was even some fringe speculation during Watergate after VP Agnew resigned that Nixon appointed Kissinger who was a naturalized citizen as vice president as he could not run for and be elected president but if Nixon resigned, he could become president. Don’t know if that view was accurate and many who detest Kissinger would have been aghast if it had happened, but it did not come to pass. Yet some writers speculated on it. Dual citizens
This is another thing secure countries are relaxed about. Mark Carney was the governor of the Central Bank of Canada from 2008 to 2013. Having done an exemplary job and being a dual citizen of Canada and the United Kingdom, he was then made governor of the Bank of England from 2013 to 2020. Economist Stanley Fischer, who was born in what is now Zambia (the former Northern Rhodesia) has dual citizenship — Israeli and American. He was chief economist of the World Bank, then from 2005 to 2013 was governor of the Bank of Israel. In 2014, President Obama appointed him vice chairman of the Federal Reserve. He stepped down for personal reasons in 2017. Jennifer Granholm is both a Canadian and naturalized American citizen and was born in Canada. She was elected and served as governor of Michigan from 2003 to 2011 and has now been appointed secretary of energy by President Biden. What is my point behind these examples? The US, the UK, Canada and Israel did not care if they were dual citizens or naturalized. They just wanted the best and most qualified citizens. Why exclude citizens based on having more than one citizenship or being naturalized? I would suggest in a country like ours, where so many left for opportunity and necessity, why discriminate against them if they want to engage in public service when they return? Recovery of citizenship was a good step but why be so insecure and stop there? The same for naturalized citizens. You must really want to be part of the country if you take an actual step of taking citizenship. If one argues but they left or they got naturalized for opportunistic reasons, my answer is so what? If they are lousy or disloyal, then remove them or vote them out. Are we that insecure? Or jealous?

titles: Manila releases advance payment for AstraZeneca
articles_content: THE Manila City Government on Friday advanced its payment for 800,000 doses of AstraZeneca vaccine for individuals infected with coronavirus disease 2019 (Covid-19). Mayor Francisco “Isko Moreno” Domagoso authorized the release of P38.4 million to the British-Swedish company. “Fortunately, the national government allowed LGUs (local government units) to fast-track the procurement process,” Domagoso said. “I am thankful for that.” The Government Procurement Reform Act allows advance payment equivalent to a maximum of 15 percent of the cost of government-financed projects. The amount released by the city is equivalent to 15.36 percent of its P250 million allotment. President Rodrigo Duterte, however, signed a memorandum order increasing the limit for advanced payments for the purchase of the coronavirus vaccines.

titles: Cebu Archbishop Palma tests positive for Covid
articles_content: CEBU Archbishop Jose Palma has tested positive for the coronavirus disease 2019 (Covid-19). “He (Archbishop Palma) tested positive at 10 p.m. (Thursday),” said Cebu Archdiocese Msgr. Joseph Tan on Friday. Tan said that Archbishop Palma was not feeling well earlier on Thursday and wanted to be confined in a hospital. The archbishop is confined at the Perpetual Succour and remains in stable condition. “His body felt tired, he was coughing and felt really tired. So he had a swab test,” Msgr. Tan told The Manila Times in Visayan. Msgr. Tan said Archbishop Palma did not have any recent travels outside Cebu and they do not have any idea where the archbishop could have contracted the virus. “Our main concern is to make sure he gets out of the hospital,” he added. Tan said that Archbishop Palma’s symptoms include general fatigue and mild cough. “Let us all pray for his steady and speedy recovery,” said The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Cebu in a statement.

titles: Reopening of cinemas even at 20% capacity pushed
articles_content: TRADE Secretary Ramon Lopez is urging local governments under the general community quarantine (GCQ) to allow cinemas to operate even at 20 percent capacity to generate more jobs to people affected by the pandemic. During the Laging Handa public briefing on state-run PTV-4 held on Friday, Lopez said that the Department of Trade and Industry’s (DTI) recommendation was based on its observation that those cinemas allowed to open in areas under modified general community quarantine (MGCQ) did not result in higher cases of the coronavirus disease 2019. “Remember, most of the areas in the country are under MGCQ and only about eight places, including the National Capital Region are in GCQ. In areas under MGCQ outside Metro Manila, cinemas are allowed to be open but our observations showed that it did not result in the spike of Covid-19 cases,” he said in Filipino. “Its all about … compliance to health protocols.” Lopez also said that the DTI’s push for cinemas’ reopening is just meant to sustain the gradual reopening of the economy. “We are not violating any laws here. If the LGUs (local government units) are not comfortable, lets start with allowing cinemas to operate at 20 or 30 percent capacity. The only difference is that there will be jobs available for the people,” he added.

titles: UN chief urges global plan to reverse unfair vaccine process
articles_content: UNITED NATIONS: UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres sharply criticized the “wildly uneven and unfair” distribution of coronavirus disease 2019 (Covid-19) vaccines on Wednesday, saying 10 countries have administered 75 percent of all vaccinations and demanding a global effort to get all people in every nation vaccinated as soon as possible. The UN chief told a high-level meeting of the UN Security Council that 130 countries have not received a single dose of vaccine and declared that “at this critical moment, vaccine equity is the biggest moral test before the global community.” Guterres called for an urgent Global Vaccination Plan to bring together those with the power to ensure fair vaccine distribution — scientists, vaccine producers and those who can fund the effort. The secretary-general called on the world’s major economic powers in the Group of 20 to establish an emergency task force to establish a plan and coordinate its implementation and financing. He said the task force should have the capacity “to mobilize the pharmaceutical companies and key industry and logistics actors.” Guterres said Friday’s meeting of the Group of Seven major industrialized nations “can create the momentum to mobilize the necessary financial resources.” British Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab, whose country holds the Security Council presidency this month, urged the UN’s most powerful body to adopt a resolution calling for ceasefires in conflict zones to allow the delivery of Covid-19 vaccines. Thirteen ministers were scheduled to address the meeting on improving access to Covid-19 including US Secretary of State Antony Blinken. Britain says more than 160 million people are at risk of being excluded from coronavirus vaccinations because they live in countries engulfed in conflict and instability, including Yemen, Syria, South Sudan, Somalia and Ethiopia. “Global vaccination coverage is essential to beating coronavirus,” Raab said ahead of the meeting. “That is why the UK is calling for a vaccination cease-fire to allow Covid-19 vaccines to reach people living in conflict zones and for a greater global team effort to deliver equitable access.” Britain’s UN ambassador, Barbara Woodward said: “Humanitarian organizations and UN agencies need the full backing of the council to be able to carry out the job we are asking them to do.” Woodward said cease-fires have been used to carry out vaccinations, pointing to a two-day pause in fighting in Afghanistan in 2001 that enabled 35,000 health workers and volunteers to vaccinate 5.7 million children under the age of 5 against polio. Britain has drafted a Security Council resolution that Woodward said the UK hopes will be adopted in the coming weeks. Mexican Foreign Minister Marcelo Ebrard said Tuesday that Mexico will stress the importance of equal access for all countries to Covid-19 vaccines at the council meeting. He was sharply critical that countries that produce the vaccine have high vaccination rates while Latin American countries have problems obtaining any vaccines. The coronavirus has infected more than 109 million people and killed at least 2.4 million of them. But many countries have not yet started vaccination programs and even rich nations are facing shortages of vaccine doses as manufacturers struggle to ramp up production. The World Health Organization’s COVAX program, an ambitious project to buy and deliver coronavirus vaccines for the world’s poorest people, has already missed its own goal of beginning coronavirus vaccinations in poor countries at the same time that shots were rolled out in rich countries. Numerous developing countries have rushed in recent weeks to sign their own private deals to buy vaccines, unwilling to wait for COVAX. Woodward said Britain supports reserving 5% of COVAX doses as a “last resort” buffer to ensure that high-risk populations have access to Covid-19 vaccines.

titles: Are supervisors still relevant in the next normal?
articles_content:
Almost a year ago, Josh Dzieza, investigations editor and feature writer at “The Verge,” wrote an article that could scare today’s Supervisors. The handwriting on the wall looks clear, “In warehouses, call centers and other sectors, intelligent machines are managing humans, and they’re making work more stressful, grueling, and dangerous.” Robo-bosses
Dzieza continues, “The robots are watching over hotel housekeepers, telling them which room to clean and tracking how quickly they do it. They’re managing software developers, monitoring their clicks and scrolls and docking their pay if they work too slowly. They’re listening to call center workers, telling them what to say, how to say it, and keeping them constantly, maximally busy. While we’ve been watching the horizon for the self-driving trucks, perpetually five years away, the robots arrived in the form of the supervisor, the foreman, the middle manager.” Robotics and AI (artificial intelligence) have arrived, and workers in many countries are worried. Dzieza said, “For many of them, their greatest fear isn’t that robots might come for their jobs: it’s that robots have already become their boss.” While many employees detest the thought of being supervised by a robot, a recent survey by Kevin Kruse, CEO of LEADx, revealed that more than 20 percent of workers would want to replace their boss with a generic robot. The LEADx survey results could be unsettling for some supervisors, considering that supervisors have come a long way since the medieval times and have been permanent fixtures in today’s workplace. Origin of supervisor
According to Wikipedia, the word “supervisor” came from the Medieval Latin verb “supervidēre,” meaning “to oversee.” The prefix super (also supra) means “over” or “above”, while the Latin vidēre means “to see.” Literally, to supervise means to see from above. The supervisor is also known by several names — foreman, boss, overseer, monitor, area coordinator or sometimes “gaffer.” In the factory, the supervisor is in a low-level management position. In the academe, the supervisor could be one of the most senior in the staff, such as a Professor who oversees a PhD dissertation. Sometimes, people in the same job grade as the Supervisor are also classified as supervisors, even if they do not supervise other people. Supervisors’ dilemma
Perhaps, supervisors are one of the most misunderstood and stressed people in the workplace. They have productivity-conscious bosses above them and sometimes uncooperative subordinates below them. They’re like the “bibingka,” the Filipino rice cake cooked with fire under it and burning coal on top of it. The first time I was promoted to be a supervisor came as a surprise. I had no training to be one. It seemed that my boss perceived how good I was at doing my clerical tasks. As a reward, I was promoted! Then my headaches began. Here’s why: Like I said, I never had any supervisory skills training before I got promoted. It felt like I was thrown into the pool, and I heard my boss shouting, “Swim!” I was good at technical work, but I never did management or supervisory work. The scope of my job was unclear at first. My friends and fellow employees suddenly became my subordinates. I was not sure if they were ready to accept me as their boss. My sense sometimes told me that some, not all, resented my promotion since many of them had more seniority and longevity in the company. Suddenly, I had two jobs — doing my own and minding the jobs of others. Somehow, I thought that I was programmed to be a rank and file. I had to reprogram my thinking and thought process to be like a manager. It was tough without support from my Manager. To those supervisors who now experience the same dilemma I encountered early in my career, here are some suggestions you might find useful: – Role clarification. First understand your new role — including what you’re supposed to do and what you’re not supposed to do. Ask your boss about his/her expectations and the limits of your authority. Once you’re clear on the parameters with your boss, clarify the same with your subordinates. Whenever possible, take time to discuss this with your subordinates as a group and on a one-on-one basis. Listen to their reactions — verbal and nonverbal — and to what is not being said. – Remain professional at all times. As a new “boss,” you need to establish professional working relationships with your bosses, peers and subordinates. Focus on issues and the tasks at hand, rather than on personalities. Do not shoot the messenger who brings you unsavory news. Be seen as a leader and enabler of others – not bossy, not pushing too hard. – Refrain from office politics. At all cost, avoid corridor or water-cooler politics. Do not side with one party to a dispute that you must arbitrate. Remain neutral, objective and fair always. Don’t get tempted to listen to juicy gossip, lest one day you’re subject of it, too. – Raise your managerial skills. Always sharpen your saw, as Covey said. While the management principles hardly change, the practice is influenced by a number of change drivers in business and in life. Continue to be a student of the art and science of management. Learn the science and adapt it to your working environment. C-3PO as boss?
First-time supervisors must not be wary about lack of supervisory, managerial or leadership skills. They are easily learned from the right sources. What is more worrisome is the development in technology that enables the machines to take over the supervisors’ jobs. The other aspect to worry about is the reaction of workers to the idea of changing a human supervisor with a robot. The younger employees are more willing and ready to trade their current boss with C-3PO. Many employees join a company. But Gallup says employees resign from their bosses. The Gallup survey speaks volumes. Bad bosses are perhaps the major reason for low employee engagement. The LEADx survey says that roughly 30 percent of employees would replace their boss with a friendly humanoid robot-like C-3PO. Recent employee engagement surveys confirm that 30 percent of employees worldwide are disengaged. Coincidence? The LEADx survey revealed the main reasons why employees would replace their bosses with robots: a) they don’t like their boss; 2) their boss is biased; 3) their boss lacks competence; and 4) their boss lacks people skills and empathy. The onus is on supervisors to prove that they are still relevant in the workplace now and in the future. Obviously, humans have characteristics that robots still don’t have, as we write. If the developers and programmers can find a way to program empathy, compassion and love into the DNA of the robots, the supervisors would be among the endangered species. The surveys tend to send a strong warning. People, especially the young, are willing to work with technology, especially in humanoid form, perhaps like Daryl (Data Analyzing Robot Youth Lifeform) in the 1985 movie. People will prefer to have a robot boss if it means getting rid of their bad supervisor. To good supervisors, I say that there’s still a niche for you. As Brian Tracy said, “Only about two percent of people can work entirely without supervision. We call them Leaders.” To the employees, I reiterate my long-time admonition, “Take care of your boss now, the next could be worse — or not human.” Ernie Cecilia is the chairman of the Human Capital Committee of the American Chamber of Commerce of the Philippines (AMCHAM); Co-Chairman of the Employers Confederation of the Philippines’ (ECOP’s) TWG on Labor Policy and Social Issues; and past president of the People Management Association of the Philippines (PMAP). He can be reached at erniececilia@gmail.com

titles: This pandemic: A punctuated equilibrium
articles_content: We won’t lose hope. When the sun goes down, the stars will come out. – Anon THE pandemic has punctuated our equilibrium. Applied to various life areas such as in the disciplines — in physics, psychology, economics, management, etc., the term “equilibrium” means balance. Physics-wise, if the resultant of forces on opposite sides of the lever is zero, then there is equilibrium. This pandemic: A punctuated equilibrium. We are witnessing a punctuated equilibrium that has slammed aspects of life. Supply and demand such as for food and health out balance each other; unstable prices of such goods results. Psychology-wise, our mental schemata do not fit the actual environment we are in, be this in our cultural, physical or social environment. Our expectations based on the normal life we knew are incredibly incompatible with the new normal life the pandemic brought about. We need cognitive equilibrium to provide us an intellectual and emotional balance. The social distancing protocols and economic concerns caused by Covid-19 have imposed on us feelings of personal isolation and uncertainty. Obviously, to keep our sanity, we do need equilibrium. Punctuated equilibrium. As we try to calm our nerves in adjusting to this new normal, what can we do to redirect this seismic change? Let us draw understanding of this pandemic from the origin of what paleontologists identified as punctuated equilibrium (PE). The data base explains that there were five PE’s in the last 500 million years. It was a huge meteor or volcanic fury or both, as earth history explains, that caused the ecosystem to change drastically causing the dinosaurs to die. There were a few cold-blooded reptile survivors including crocodiles, but the new ecosystem favored the warm-blooded mammals. Why, because they were able to adapt to the severe weather changes. The PE theory “brings about change,” “after long periods of stability in the characteristics of an organism.” Then comes “short periods of rapid change during which new forms appear.” <dictionary. cambridge.org › dictionary › english › punct…> Similarly, in this pandemic, we are experiencing drastic change. “So, what should be our response to this equilibrium that has been punctuated in our ecosystem? Are we like dinosaurs, or mammals?” Why did the mammals thrive, besides luck? The answer is “Adaptability, adaptability and adaptability.” <www.thoughtworks. com › insights › blog › surviving-o..>. Adapting, would mean a change — a change in us? The equilibrium we need. It is not only a change on market forces that we would seek in the next stage of this pandemic. After a few months of relative calm, “we’ve started to see some striking evolution” of the virus. Biologist Trevor Bedford of the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center in Seattle wrote of the new strains on Twitter last week. <www.manila times.net › 2021/01/ 20 › news › national>. Unlettered about viruses, most of us did not expect the rise of Covid-19 mutations. They imply an uncertain end of the pandemic, threatening everyone’s psychological health. Gripped with constant fear of contracting the virus or its mutations, we worry over total loss of livelihood, disruption of quality education, a prolonged restriction of social contact, and a host of other uncertainties. Anxiety and/or depression impacts on us both as individuals and on our communities. To lift our spirits, let us count on the positives — the communal spirit of the Filipino which has openly asserted itself many times over. The nimble way is another welcomed change, unlike in prepandemic days, of more government departments in attending to healthcare, education and work interventions to battle with stress and sickness. While physical distance protocol narrows our social life, let’s be thankful for more time we gain for family, creating meaningful relations that we may have failed to nurture due to our professional activities. And thanks for increased awareness to reduce air pollution and greenhouse gases emissions. All these positive developments, we hope would be sustained as we, with much uncertainty, try to adapt to the new normal. Redirecting punctuated equilibrium. Unlike the dinosaurs during the biological PT, we are not experiencing evolving physically. Thankfully, we had temporary stability during massive lockdowns, making us quite used to quarantines; some businesses and tourist spots were allowed to open. However, this short-lived seemingly stable phase, being disturbed by the new pandemic strains coming down on hapless victims, is robbing us of hope that some good change is near at hand. The change we hope for, amidst this massive global-wide uncertainty, is a stable state if there will be. Sadly, the PT theory considered, it proved to be short-lived, punctuated. Thus, to calm our fears, let us stay resilient; hold tight to optimism. Nurture a sense of control. Converse with ourselves. Keep tab of [our] own emotions.” Let’s stay connected with our own family and friends. Bond with the wider community. Extend help where we can. Hold on to hope and faith. This is a challenging phase of the equilibrium. But out of this experience, there comes learning that can “help us build a bridge to the future that is beyond this current crisis.” <www.continuousbreakthruz.com› blog › punctuated-e…> Hold on to our faith and hope in Him. “And when such a future comes, let us be ready and willing to embrace the change.” Putting our heart and mind on this change could be the beginning of a creative tension to initiate a healthy transformation. “There will be no normal to come back to because it is us who will have changed! Our perspectives will have shifted.” In such a punctuated equilibrium, there still is a future to build! Email: ttumapon@liceo.edu.ph

titles: PH signs ‘no liability’ deal with Pfizer, AstraZeneca
articles_content: THE Philippine government has signed indemnification agreements with vaccine makers Pfizer and AstraZeneca, vaccine czar Carlito Galvez Jr. said on Wednesday. “Nakapagpirma na po at naisumite na po natin ang mga requirement kasama po dito ang indemnification agreements para sa Pfizer at AstraZeneca, so napirmahan na po namin iyon (We have already signed and submitted all requirements, including the indemnification agreements for Pfizer and AstraZeneca, so we have already signed that),” Galvez said during a Laging Handa public briefing on Wednesday. The indemnification agreements provide that firms will have no liability if ever recipients of vaccines experience adverse effects. Once Pfizer and AstraZeneca sign the deal, the Covax facility can proceed with the delivery of the vaccines to the Philippines. Galvez attributed the delay of the arrival of vaccines from the Covax facility to discussions on the indemnification agreement between the Philippine government and the vaccine manufacturers.

titles: Palace: ‘New normal’ possible for Covid-free areas
articles_content: AREAS with no transmission of coronavirus disease 2019 (Covid-19) may be placed under the less stricter “new normal” classification, Malacañang said on Wednesday. In an interview with state-run PTV-4, Palace spokesman Harry Roque Jr. said the Inter-Agency Task Force for the Management of Emerging Infectious Diseases (IATF) was crafting the do’s and don’ts for the possible transition to “new normal” of areas with zero transmission in the past month. “‘Yan naman po talaga ay napagusapan na ng ating IATF at ang inaantay lang po natin ay yung mga do’s and don’ts (That is being discussed by the IATF and we are just waiting for the dos and don’ts),” Roque said when asked of possibly declaring some areas under the “new normal.” Roque, who is also with the IATF, said he would raise again the declaration of the “new normal” in some areas when they meet again. “Hayaan niyo po, sa susunod na IATF [meeting] ay bubuksan ko po muli itong usapin na ito dahil tayo po talaga yung nag move na magdeklara na tayo ng new normal sa mga lugar na wala na pong transmission ng Covid-19 (Don’t worry, in the next IATF meeting, I will once again open this topic because we are the one that moved to declare new normal in areas that no longer have Covid-19 transmission),” he said. “Meron naman po tayong mga lugar na natigil na po ang transmission ng Covid-19 (There are now areas where the Covid-19 transmission already stopped),” he added, without providing other details as to which areas in the country have no coronavirus transmissions. The “new normal” classification used to be the fifth, lowest quarantine classification before the IATF removed it in June. According to IATF’s guidelines on the implementation of community quarantine, “new normal” refers to “emerging behaviors, situations, and minimum public health standards that will be institutionalized in common or routine practices and remain even after the pandemic while the disease is not totally eradicated through means such as widespread immunization.” “These include actions that will become second nature to the general public as well as policies such as bans on large gatherings that will continue to remain in force,” it added. To date, there are only four levels of community quarantine: enhanced community quarantine, which is the strictest; modified enhanced community quarantine, general community quarantine (GCQ), and the modified general community quarantine (MGCQ). For the month of February, areas under GCQ are Metro Manila, Cordillera Administrative Region, Batangas, Tacloban City, Iligan City, Davao del Norte, Davao City, and Lanao del Sur. The rest of the country is currently under MGCQ, the most lenient quarantine classification and the phase before the “new normal.” Current community quarantine classifications are set to lapse after February 28. As of Monday, the country has over 550,000 cases of the coronavirus. Over 510,000 have recovered, while more than 11,000 have died from the disease.

titles: EU to launch program for ‘second generation’ Covid-19 vaccines
articles_content: BRUSSELS: The EU will launch a program to study Covid-19 variants and produce “second generation” vaccines against future strains, the bloc’s president has said. The “HERA incubator” program, which begins Wednesday, will bring together the pharmaceutical industry, laboratories, health authorities and researchers, Ursula von der Leyen told French daily Les Echos on Tuesday. “The virus has evolved and will continue to evolve,” said a spokesperson for the bloc —  which has been criticized for its a slow rollout of vaccines so far. “It is important we prepare for mutations.” Member states will also be asked to contribute additional funds so the EU can adapt and modify contracts already signed with vaccine providers and secure doses against future variants, Bloomberg reported. The EU Commission did not comment when contacted by Agence France-Presse. With delays to deliveries of three already-authorized vaccines by AstraZeneca, Pfizer/BioNTech and Moderna, the EU’s medicines regulator is under pressure from European capitals to speed more into service. US pharmaceutical giant Johnson & Johnson is the latest to apply for authorization for its coronavirus vaccine in the EU with a decision possible by the middle of March, Europe’s drugs regulator said Tuesday.

titles: Duterte signs law to cushion impact of pandemic on financial institutions
articles_content: PRESIDENT Rodrigo Duterte has signed into law the Financial Institutions Strategic Transfer (FIST) Act which aims to cushion the impact of the coronavirus disease 2019 (Covid-19) pandemic on financial institutions. Presidential spokesman Harry Roque Jr. confirmed this on Wednesday. “Napirmahan na po bilang isang batas ng Presidente ang RA (Republic Act) 11523 o mas kilala bilang Financial Institution Strategic Transfer or FIST Act (The President signed into law RA (Republic Act) 11523 also known as the Financial Institutions Strategic Transfer or FIST Act).” Malacañang thanked Congress for passing the bill, which Roque said was needed amid the crisis brought about by the pandemic. “Napapanahon na po ang pagpasa ng FIST law lalo na sa ngayon na tayo po ay nasa panahon ng pandemya (The passage of FIST law is timely, especially now that we are facing a pandemic).” Senate Bill 1849 and House Bill 6816 which provide mechanisms to allow banks and financial institutions to dispose and transfer non-performing assets and loans had been certified as urgent by the President.

titles: WHO: 13 Mideast nations have new variant cases
articles_content: BEIRUT: Coronavirus case numbers are stabilizing in parts of the Middle East but the situation remains critical, with more than a dozen countries reporting cases of new variants, the World Health Organization said on Monday. Ahmed al-Mandhari, director of WHO’s eastern Mediterranean region, which comprises most of the Middle East, said in a press briefing from Cairo that at least one of the three new coronavirus variants was reported in the 13 countries in the region. He did not name the countries. All three of the new variants are more contagious, according to WHO. Al-Mandhari said there are nearly 6 million confirmed cases of coronavirus in the region and about 140,000 deaths. WHO urged people to continue taking precautionary measures against the virus. The organization said 6.3 million vaccinations have been administered in 12 countries in the eastern Mediterranean. “Vaccinations are a turning point in facing the virus but the vaccines alone are not enough,” al-Mandhari said, adding that social distancing, wearing masks and keeping clean remain the main ways to fight the spread of the virus. He said as many people as possible should be vaccinated before they come into contact with any of the new variants of the virus. A healthcare worker receives Pfizer-BioNTech Covid-19 vaccine during a nationwide vaccination program at the American University Medical Center in Beirut, Lebanon, Sunday, Feb. 14, 2021. AP PHOTO Al-Mandhari said 37,000 coronavirus vaccine doses from the global Covax initiative will arrive in the Palestinian territories and 94,000 should arrive in Tunisia in the coming weeks. The program seeks to provide vaccines to developing nations. Al-Mandhari said overall the number of new coronavirus cases in the region has stabilized, despite increases in some Gulf nations and Lebanon. Lebanon has been one of the hardest hit countries in the region in recent weeks with hospitals working at near maximum capacity amid a nationwide lockdown. Lebanon began a vaccination campaign Sunday. A nation of 6 million people including a million Syrian refugees, Lebanon has confirmed nearly 340,000 cases. Iran remains the eastern Mediterranean country with the highest number of confirmed cases at about 1.5 million.

titles: Covid-19 shots might be tweaked if variants get worse
articles_content: The makers of Covid-19 vaccines are figuring out how to tweak their recipes against worrisome virus mutations — and regulators are looking to flu as a blueprint if and when the shots need an update. “It’s not really something you can sort of flip a switch, do overnight,” cautioned Richard Webby, who directs a World Health Organization flu center from St. Jude Children’s Research Hospital. Viruses mutate constantly and it takes just the right combination of particular mutations to escape vaccination. But studies are raising concern that first-generation Covid-19 vaccines don’t work as well against a mutant that first emerged in South Africa as they do against other versions circulating around the world. The good news: Many of the new Covid-19 vaccines are made with new, flexible technology that’s easy to upgrade. What’s harder: Deciding if the virus has mutated enough that it’s time to modify vaccines — and what changes to make. “When do you pull the trigger?” asked Norman Baylor, a former Food and Drug Administration vaccine chief. “This is a moving target right now.” The WHO and FDA are looking to the global flu vaccine system in deciding how to handle similar decisions about Covid-19 shots. Influenza mutates much faster than the coronavirus, and flu shots have to be adjusted just about every year. National centers around the globe collect circulating flu viruses and track how they’re evolving. They send samples to WHO-designated labs for more sophisticated “antigenic” testing to determine vaccine strength. The WHO and regulators then agree on the year’s vaccine recipe and manufacturers get to work. For Covid-19 vaccines, Webby said a critical step is establishing a similar surveillance and testing network to flag the mutations that matter. Today, there’s wide geographic variability in tracking and testing mutated versions. For example, Britain does more testing of the changing viral genome than the United States. Three variants first discovered in Britain, South Africa and Brazil are worrisome because of combinations of mutations that make them more contagious. On Sunday, US researchers reported a still different mutation found in seven variants that have cropped up in several states. No one yet knows if this mutation makes the virus easier to spread but the report, not yet vetted by other scientists, urges further research to find out. In this Jan. 22, 2021 file photo, empty vials of the Pfizer-BioNTech Covid-19 vaccine are seen at a vaccination center at the University of Nevada in Las Vegas. AP PHOTO Just because a variant is more contagious doesn’t mean it also will be impervious to vaccination. But the variant first identified in South Africa is raising concerns. Columbia University’s David Ho put blood samples from people given the Pfizer or Moderna vaccines into lab dishes with the mutated virus. Vaccine-produced antibodies still protected, but they were much less potent. Preliminary test results of two other vaccine candidates — from Novavax and Johnson & Johnson — soon backed up those findings. Both still protected but were weaker when tested in South Africa, where that variant dominates, than when tested elsewhere. A far smaller test of the AstraZeneca vaccine in South Africa has raised questions about its effect. “If the virus were able to make an additional mutation or two, it could escape even more,” Ho warned. If fully immunized people start getting hospitalized with mutated virus, “that’s when the line gets crossed,” said Dr. Paul Offit, a Children’s Hospital of Philadelphia vaccine expert who advises the FDA. That hasn’t happened yet, but “we should get ready,” he added. Moderna is about to explore one option: Could a third dose of the original vaccine boost immunity enough to fend off some variants even if it’s not an exact match? Columbia’s Ho said it’s a good idea to test because people may “still have plenty of cushion” if their overall antibody levels are very high. In this Jan. 22, 2021 file photo, Tina Killebrew, a certified medical assistant, prepares a dose of the Pfizer-BioNTech Covid-19 vaccine at a vaccination center at the University of Nevada, Las Vegas. AP PHOTO Major manufacturers also are developing experimental variant vaccines, just in case. Covid-19 vaccines produce antibodies that recognize the spike protein that coats the coronavirus. When the virus mutates, sometimes the spike protein is changed in key areas so the vaccine-produced antibodies have a harder time recognizing it. The Pfizer and Moderna vaccines are made with a piece of genetic code called messenger RNA that tells the body how to make some harmless copies of the spike protein that train immune cells. To update the vaccine, they can simply change the payload: swap out the original genetic code with mRNA for the mutated spike protein. The AstraZeneca vaccine and the Johnson & Johnson shot expected to roll out soon are made with cold viruses engineered to sneak a spike protein gene into the body. Adjusting their vaccines requires growing cold viruses with the mutated gene, a little more complex than the mRNA approach but not nearly as laborious as reformulating old-fashioned flu shots. The Novavax vaccine also in final-stage testing is made with a lab-grown copy of the spike protein that also could be tweaked to match mutations. First-generation Covid-19 vaccines were tested in tens of thousands of people to be sure they work and are safe — research that took many months. Simply changing the recipe to better target virus mutations won’t require repeating those studies in thousands of people, Dr. Peter Marks, the FDA’s vaccine chief, recently told the American Medical Association. FDA still is finalizing requirements, but Marks said the agency intends to “be pretty nimble.” If an updated vaccine is needed, tests in a few hundred people likely would be enough to tell if it triggers a good immune response, he said. But an even bigger question: If only some places face vaccine-resistant virus mutants, would authorities want variant-only shots or vaccines that protect against two kinds in one jab? After all, flu vaccines protect against three or four different types in one shot. Companies would first have to perform some basic research to be sure a variant-only version properly revs up the immune system, said the Immunization Action Coalition’s John Grabenstein, a former Merck vaccine executive. Then a combination shot would need more testing to be sure there’s an equal response to both types.

titles: Virus may never go away but could change into mild annoyance
articles_content: NEW DELHI: What if Covid-19 never goes away? Experts say it’s likely that some version of the disease will linger for years. But what it will look like in the future is less clear. Will the coronavirus, which has already killed more than 2 million people worldwide, eventually be eliminated by a global vaccination campaign, like smallpox? Will dangerous new variants evade vaccines? Or will the virus stick around for a long time, transforming into a mild annoyance, like the common cold? Eventually, the virus known as SARS-CoV-2 will become yet “another animal in the zoo,” joining the many other infectious diseases that humanity has learned to live with, predicted Dr. T. Jacob John, who studies viruses and was at the helm of India’s efforts to tackle polio and HIV/AIDS. FILE – In this an. 24, 2021, file photo, people stand near a sign as they wait in line to receive the first of two doses of the Pfizer vaccine for COVID-19 at a one-day vaccination clinic set up in an Amazon.com facility in Seattle and operated by Virginia Mason Franciscan Health. Scientists say it’s still too early to predict the future of the coronavirus, but many doubt it will ever go away entirely. (AP Photo/Ted S. Warren, File) But no one knows for sure. The virus is evolving rapidly, and new variants are popping up in different countries. The risk of these new variants was underscored when Novavax Inc. found that the company’s vaccine did not work as well against mutated versions circulating in Britain and South Africa. The more the virus spreads, experts say, the more likely it is that a new variant will become capable of eluding current tests, treatments and vaccines. For now, scientists agree on the immediate priority: Vaccinate as many people as quickly as possible. The next step is less certain and depends largely on the strength of the immunity offered by vaccines and natural infections and how long it lasts. “Are people going to be frequently subject to repeat infections? We don’t have enough data yet to know,” said Jeffrey Shaman, who studies viruses at Columbia University. Like many researchers, he believes chances are slim that vaccines will confer lifelong immunity. If humans must learn to live with Covid-19, the nature of that coexistence depends not just on how long immunity lasts, but also how the virus evolves. Will it mutate significantly each year, requiring annual shots, like the flu? Or will it pop up every few years? This question of what happens next attracted Jennie Lavine, a virologist at Emory University, who is co-author of a recent paper in Science that projected a relatively optimistic scenario: After most people have been exposed to the virus — either through vaccination or surviving infections — the pathogen “will continue to circulate, but will mostly cause only mild illness,” like a routine cold. While immunity acquired from other coronaviruses — like those that cause the common cold or SARS or MERS — wanes over time, symptoms upon reinfection tend to be milder than the first illness, said Ottar Bjornstad, a co-author of the Science paper who studies viruses at Pennsylvania State University. “Adults tend not to get very bad symptoms if they’ve already been exposed,” he said.  FILE – In this Nov. 12, 2020, file photo, people walk in a market to shop ahead of the Diwalli festival in New Delhi, India. Scientists say it’s still too early to predict the future of the coronavirus, but many doubt it will ever go away entirely. (AP Photo/Manish Swarup, File) The prediction in the Science paper is based on an analysis of how other coronaviruses have behaved over time and assumes that SAR-CoV-2 continues to evolve, but not quickly or radically. The 1918 flu pandemic could offer clues about the course of Covid-19. That pathogen was an H1N1 virus with genes that originated in birds, not a coronavirus. At the time, no vaccines were available. The United States Centers for Disease Control and Prevention estimates that a third of the world’s population became infected. Eventually, after infected people either died or developed immunity, the virus stopped spreading quickly. It later mutated into a less virulent form, which experts say continues to circulate seasonally. “Very commonly the descendants of flu pandemics become the milder seasonal flu viruses we experience for many years,” said Stephen Morse, who studies viruses at Columbia University. It’s not clear yet how future mutations in SARS-CoV-2 will shape the trajectory of the current disease. As new variants emerge — some more contagious, some more virulent and some possibly less responsive to vaccines — scientists are reminded how much they don’t yet know about the future of the virus, said Mark Jit, who studies viruses at the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine. “We’ve only known about this virus for about a year, so we don’t yet have data to show its behavior over five years or 10 years,” he said. Of the more than 12 billion coronavirus vaccine shots being made in 2021, rich countries have bought about 9 billion, and many have options to buy more. This inequity is a threat since it will result in poorer countries having to wait longer for the vaccine, during which time the disease will continue to spread and kill people, said Ian MacKay, who studies viruses at the University of Queensland. A couple walk along a boulevard in Barcelona, Spain, Sunday, Jan. 17, 2021. Scientists say it’s still too early to predict the future of the coronavirus, but many doubt it will ever go away entirely. (AP Photo/Emilio Morenatti) That some vaccines seem less effective against the new strains is worrisome, but since the shots provide some protection, vaccines could still be used to slow or stop the virus from spreading, said Ashley St. John, who studies immune systems at Duke-NUS Medical School in Singapore. Dr. Gagandeep Kang, an infectious diseases expert at Christian Medical College at Vellore in southern India, said the evolution of the virus raises new questions: At what stage does the virus become a new strain? Will countries need to re-vaccinate from scratch? Or could a booster dose be given? “These are questions that you will have to address in the future,” Kang said. The future of the coronavirus may contrast with other highly contagious diseases that have been largely beaten by vaccines that provide lifelong immunity — such as measles. The spread of measles drops off after many people have been vaccinated. But the dynamic changes over time with new births, so outbreaks tend to come in cycles, explained Dr. Jayaprakash Muliyil, who studies epidemics and advises India on virus surveillance. Unlike measles, kids infected with Covid-19 don’t always exhibit clear symptoms and could still transmit the disease to vulnerable adults. That means countries cannot let their guard down, he said. Another unknown is the long-term impact of Covid-19 on patients who survive but are incapacitated for months, Kang said. The “quantification of this damage” — how many people can’t do manual labor or are so exhausted that they can’t concentrate — is key to understanding the full consequences of the disease. “We haven’t had a lot of diseases that have affected people on a scale like this,” she said.

titles: Hate crimes increasingly target Asians in America
articles_content: The Covid-19 pandemic is apparently not the only malady gripping the United States these days. There is also hate. In this image from video, Michael van der Veen, an attorney for former President Donald Trump, answers a question from Sen. Bill Cassidy, R-La., during the second impeachment trial of former President Donald Trump in the Senate at the U.S. Capitol in Washington, Friday, Feb. 12, 2021. AP PHOTO US media recently reported an alarming increase of hate crimes committed against Asians and Asian Americans. These reports follow nearly a year’s worth of news about Black Lives Matter protests against the deaths of Breonna Taylor and George Floyd, two of the many African Americans killed by law enforcers. Earlier this year, America, along with the rest of the world, was also shocked by protestors storming the US Capitol in an attempt to disrupt the certification of its presidential elections. They were successful, but only for a short while. Now, the immediate past US president Donald Trump is on trial after his second impeachment. Not a few are also blaming Mr. Trump for the increase in hate crimes. By referring to Covid-19 as the China or Wuhan virus, the former president may have made Asians and Asian Americans the target of violence, as well as bigotry and xenophobia. Russell Jeung, chairman of the Asian American studies department at San Francisco State University, told USA Today, “When President Trump began and insisted on using the term ‘China virus,’ we saw that hate speech really led to hate violence.” He added, “That sort of political rhetoric and that sort of anti-Asian climate has continued to this day.” Jeung created a tracker to monitor hate crimes against Asian Americans and Pacific Islanders (AAPI). His website, Stop AAPI Hate, recorded some 2,500 discrimination cases across the United States from March to August 2020. USA Today reported recently that the figure had risen to 2,808 by yearend. Other groups tracking those hate crimes corroborate the trend. The AAPI website said the most common type of discrimination was verbal harassment and name calling, 70.6 percent of the reports. Physical assault, the fourth most common type, represented 8.7 percent of the reported incidents. The victims varied from children to the elderly. The plurality of those reporting the incidents were ethnically Chinese, 40.4 percent and those of Filipino ethnicity, 7.6 percent. The same USA Today story mentioned a Filipino American, 61-year-old Noel Quintana, who suffered facial lacerations after he was attacked on the New York City subway by someone wielding a box cutter. There is worse. Earlier in January, an 84-year-old Thai living in San Francisco died after he was assaulted by someone who earlier shouted, “Go back to China.” Trump trial In fairness to Mr. Trump, he did make at least one public statement appealing for the safety of Asians and Pacific Islanders. But that was obviously too little. Also, it would be wrong to assign all the blame on the former president. Discrimination against Asians in America dates back to when Chinese immigrants were recruited to work on the US railroads. And who can forget the internment of Japanese Americans during World War 2? German Americans and other citizens descended from European countries that fought the United States did not suffer similar persecution. Still, that does not excuse Mr. Trump from stoking hate. He may be on trial for inciting an insurrection, but we hope that the US Senate finds him guilty for symbolic reasons. That may not happen, of course. As local politicians say, impeachment is a numbers game. For now, the Democrats do not seem to have the numbers needed to convict. But we still hope that US senators will vote not based on loyalty to one man but on moral principles and democratic values. As mentioned, perpetrating hate is not among the articles of impeachment. And if even Mr. Trump lost, the majority of the 74 million Americans who voted for him in 2020 still cling to lies, not only about the US elections but also about the pandemic and its economic impact. We recognize that US President Joseph Biden is rolling back many of his predecessor’s policies. By voting guilty, the US Senate reinforces the signal that America can transcend party politics and bring back decency. We hope America heals soon, not only from Covid-19 but also from moral decay.

titles: Britain’s Covid-19 cases breach 4 million
articles_content: LONDON: Another 15,144 people in Britain have tested positive for Covid-19, bringing the total number of coronavirus cases in the country to 4,013,799, according to official figures released on Friday (Saturday in Manila). The country also reported another 758 coronavirus-related deaths. The total number of coronavirus-related deaths in Britain now stands at 116,287. These figures only include the deaths of people who died within 28 days of their first positive test. The latest figures were revealed as Britain’s coronavirus R0 or reproduction number, also known as the R number, has fallen to below one for the first time since July 2020. The figure is now between 0.7 and 0.9, down from between 0.7 and 1.0 last week, according to the British government’s Scientific Advisory Group for Emergencies. The R number represents the average number of people each Covid-19 positive person goes on to infect. When the figure is above one, an outbreak can grow exponentially, but when it is below one it means the epidemic is shrinking. Meanwhile, Britain is stepping up efforts to speed up vaccine roll-out to bring the pandemic under control. More than 14 million people in Britain have been given the first jab of the coronavirus vaccine, according to the latest official figures. Britain aims to complete the vaccination of the top priority groups, which cover 15 million people, by mid-February. Downing Street has confirmed that all British adults aged 50 and older are expected to be offered a first dose of the coronavirus vaccine by early May. Britain aims to offer all adults their first dose by autumn. England is currently under the third national lockdown since the outbreak of the pandemic in the country. Similar restriction measures are also in place in Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland. To bring life back to normal, countries such as Britain, China, Germany, Russia and the United States have been racing against time to roll out coronavirus vaccines.

titles: DoH allays fears of new variant spread
articles_content: THE Department of Health (DoH) allayed fears of a spread of the more infectious B117 variant of the coronavirus disease 2019 (Covid-19) in the country after it was reported late Friday that 19 more new cases were recorded. Of the 19 new variant cases, 10 have no known links from those that were reported previously in the Cordillera Administrative Region, where a local transmission has been recorded. Health Undersecretary Maria Rosario Vergeire said during her regular segment in the Laging Handa televised briefing on Saturday that at this stage there was “no sufficient evidence to say that there is a spread or transmission that’s why we are continuously monitoring”. The DoH spokesman said that the only known local transmission of the new variant remained in clusters detected in Bontoc, Mountain Province and La Trinidad, Benguet. Vergeire said that all regions in the country, except for the Bangsamoro Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao (BARMM), were adequately represented in the latest sequencing done by the University of the Philippines – Philippine Genome Center (PGC). Vergeire said the BARMM has not submitted positive specimens but may be able to get samples next week.

titles: Covid-19 has shown humanity at its best — and worst
articles_content:
GENEVA: The World Health Organization (WHO) and United nations Children’s Fund (Unicef) have a long, deep and very special relationship. Neither of us could do what we do without the other. Unicef’s success is WHO’s success, and we are proud to be your partner on so many issues: Ebola, polio, maternal health, nutrition, infection prevention and control, primary healthcare — the list is long. Never has our partnership been more important than it is now. The Covid-19 pandemic has changed our world in ways we could never have imagined when it started just over a year ago. It’s sobering to think that on this day 12 months ago, more than 3,000 new cases of Covid-19 were reported to WHO. Yesterday (Feb. 10, 2021), 3,000 cases were reported every 15 minutes. The pandemic has held a mirror up to our world. It has shown humanity at its best and worst. It has exposed and exploited the fault lines, inequalities, injustices and contradictions of our world, within and between countries. The pandemic has also become a child emergency, with children bearing both its direct and indirect consequences. Children suffer
Children may be at lower risk of severe disease and death from Covid-19, but they have suffered many of the most severe social and economic consequences and will bear a large burden of the long-term fallout. Many children have missed out on months of schooling and have been exposed to a greater risk of violence. Girls are especially at risk in places where they may never go back to school, as they approach the age when they will go to work or be married. Since the beginning, Unicef has been, and will continue to be, an indispensable partner in ensuring that children are a primary consideration in the global response to Covid-19. Together, we have engaged, empowered and communicated with communities about the risks of Covid-19 and how to stay safe. We have developed joint guidance for the prevention and control of Covid-19 in schools; We’ve supported health workers with improved infection prevention and control, and we’ve supported them to deliver better care and psycho-social support for patients, their families and communities; we’ve procured and delivered essential supplies; We’ve provided the joint analytics that are key to an effective pandemic response; we’ve supported countries to maintain essential health services, including in humanitarian settings; And through the Access to Covid-19 Tools Accelerator and Covax, we are poised for the largest vaccination campaign in history. Vaccines are the shot in the arm we all need, literally and metaphorically. But we must also remember that vaccines will complement, not replace, the proven public health measures that countries around the world have used successfully to prevent and contain widespread transmission. As governments, institutions and individuals, we all have a role to play in stopping this pandemic with the tools we have. The pandemic will subside, but the inequalities that preceded it will still be there. Respond, recover, rebuild
There’s no vaccine for climate change, poverty or malnutrition. None of these challenges can be met by a single agency. Let me outline three areas in which the partnership between WHO and Unicef, bilaterally and through the Global Action Plan on Health and Well-Being for All, must become even deeper and stronger as we work together to support countries to respond, recover and rebuild. First, as we support countries to respond to the pandemic, we must ensure that all people and communities enjoy equitable access to life-saving vaccines, diagnostics and therapeutics — rich and poor, urban and rural, citizen and refugee. A year ago, we were defenseless against this virus. Now we can detect it with rapid diagnostic tests, we can treat it with dexamethasone and oxygen, and we can prevent it with vaccines. The urgency, ambition and resources with which vaccines have been developed must be matched by the same urgency, ambition and resources to distribute them fairly. Unicef has played a vital role in procuring vaccines and preparing countries to deploy them rapidly once they receive them. Together, we have supported 124 countries to perform readiness assessments for vaccination. But we face significant challenges. More than 130 million doses of vaccine have now been deployed globally, but 75 percent of them have been in only 10 countries that account for 60 percent of global GDP. Meanwhile, almost 130 countries, with 2.5 billion people, have yet to administer a single dose. Many of these countries are also struggling to secure the resources for testing, personal protective equipment, oxygen and medicines. I have issued a call to action to ensure that by World Health Day on April 7, vaccination of health workers is under way in all countries. Unicef can play a key role in meeting that challenge. As a trusted advocate, you can use your voice and experience in communities to build acceptance of vaccines; You can deploy your unparalleled logistics and supply capacities to deliver vaccines to the last mile. You can negotiate the best deals for the communities you serve. And you can mobilize your networks of national committees to resource this historic effort to save lives and livelihoods. Second, as we support countries to recover from the pandemic, we must support them to maintain essential health services, including routine immunization for children. The pandemic has shown that we can only meet the major crises of our time with a whole-of-government, whole-of-society approach.
